IN BERLIN, THE DOG POLICE TRY TO CURB DANGEROUS PETS 

   By ROGER COHEN   
 c.2000 N.Y. Times News Service   

   BERLIN _ With a German husband, 13 years in Germany and three
children born here, Stacy Wiedenmann of Chicago thought she had a
fair grasp of her adoptive land. But that was before Cora stepped
into her life.

   Cora is a mid-size black mongrel that scarcely advertises her
power to metamorphose a life. But take her out onto the leafy
streets of Berlin and the effect on people is dramatic: German
reserve abruptly gives way to Neapolitan gregariousness.

   How sweet, the passersby coo as they coddle Cora, how simply
lovely. When did you get her? Where? Is she already house-trained?
Well, isn't that something! How about meeting to walk our dogs and
compare notes?

   Wiedenmann, 39, is in a state of shock. She had one child, then
another, then a third, walked with them in her neighborhood and
nobody ever said a word. No candy was offered, no hair ruffled, no
age asked, no tenderness displayed. The children seemed as
invisible as Cora seems conspicuous.

   ``It's amazing; everyone suddenly talks to me,'' said
Wiedenmann, who acquired Cora a few weeks ago. ``Perhaps Germans
like dogs more than kids; certainly they talk to you through dogs.
I think they feel more comfortable because a child is personal,
perhaps too personal. So a dog becomes the ideal passport to social
contact.''

   This is a formal country, full of regulations governing
everything from times of day when children are supposed to be quiet
to the lace curtains to be placed on certain windows. But dogs defy
Germanic rules _ unleashing passions, unbuttoning the standoffish,
unveiling a charged universe of canine chaos.

   So charged that Otto Schily, the interior minister, recently
spent two days locked in dog discussions with his counterparts in
Germany's 16 states. Newspapers were full of images of raging pit
bulls and hideous dog-bite wounds as the ministers debated what to
do about the growing number of so-called Kampfhunde, or attack
dogs.

   Even the weighty weekly Die Zeit joined the fray with a
prominent article offering the view that, ``If nuclear power
stations in this country had caused as many dead and injured people
as attack dogs, they would all have been shut down a long time
ago.''

   When Berlin's interior minister proposed a ban on Kampfhunde,
the owners of such dogs called for a demonstration at which their
pets would wear a Star of David meant to symbolize what they
claimed was Hitler's comparable hounding of Jews. After protests
from the Jewish organizations, an apology was offered and the idea
withdrawn.

   Such was the general brouhaha that the ministers were unable to
reach any firm decisions. In a statement last month, they noted the
importance of appropriate training, suggested that the aggressivity
of a particular breed was not easy to assess, and left states to
determine whether certain dogs deemed dangerous should be banned,
heavily taxed, or made available only with special licenses.

   In effect, nothing changed. With approximately 200,000 dogs in
Berlin, perhaps 14,000 of them attack dogs, and an estimated 50,000
people a year getting bitten by dogs in Germany, tensions between
dog owners and their opponents continue to run high.

   ``The German dog lobby is like the Miami Cuban lobby _ nobody
can touch it,'' said Peter Schneider, a Berlin author distressed by
the ministers' indecision and this city's proliferation of dogs.
(The Berlin police reported 2,600 bites in the city last year,
compared with 1,750 in 1998.)

   ``The dog is so close to the German soul that not even an
estimated 20 tons of dog excrement a day, much of it on the street,
produces an official response.''

   It is true that while in general Germans see their role as not
only obeying laws but also enforcing them _ denouncing a car
illegally parked or a branch illegally cut from a protected tree _
they display no similar zeal for reporting canine infractions like
soiling city streets to the police. At once objects of love and
complete control, dogs thrive here.

   In an essay called ``Of Dogs and Germans,'' inspired a decade
ago by an outburst of national soul-searching over what to do with
the 5,000 dogs that had guarded the Berlin Wall and were marooned
by its fall, Schneider concluded that a German without a German
shepherd was incomplete and that the German capacity to empathize
with a dog's suffering was boundless.

   ``When Adolf Hitler was so disappointed with his Germans that he
shot himself inside his bunker, he not only left his people without
their Fuehrer, but a German shepherd without its master _ an event
that inspired Guenter Grass to write a 700-page novel entitled `Dog
Years,''' he noted.

   Wiedenmann's dog years have just begun; to keep them calm she
has enrolled Cora at Pro Dog.

   Courses at Pro Dog, an obedience school for mutts and pedigrees
alike, include seminars on dog psychology, leash technique and
human-canine communication. Training is also offered in
``high-stress dog situations,'' such as riding the subway and
taking your dog shopping or to a restaurant, all popular practices
here.

   The 10-week courses are of a kind widely followed in a country
where dog discipline is taken seriously and woods echo to the
come-hither cry of ``Platz!'' The courses lead to a qualification
called Hundefuehrerschein I, a sort of dog degree.

   An advanced degree, comparable to a dog doctorate and known as
Hundefuehrerschein II, involves advanced canine concepts such as
managing your dog without a leash. It can be had with another 10
weeks of study under Renate Albrecht, the animal psychologist in
charge.

   ``There is no such thing as a bad breed of dog, only bad and
ignorant dog owners,'' contended Albrecht, who trained in
Switzerland. ``All this talk about attack dogs is rubbish meant to
generate mass hysteria and pressure politicians to do something.
The only thing required is that people learn how to look after
their dogs.''

   nn

   To illustrate her point, Albrecht has five dogs _ Charlotte,
Amanda, Archibald, Goofy and Bandit _ four of which are
mastiff-like dogues de Bordeaux that are officially classified as
Kampfhunde. The official danger list also includes pit bulls and
American Staffordshire bull terriers.

   The dogs sprawl on her office floor, presenting nothing more
menacing than their snoring and intermittent stench. Apologizing
for the smell, Albrecht explained that a dog is not a human.

   It is enough to squeeze a dog's nose to convey displeasure,
Albrecht noted. She squeezed Amanda's amorphous nose to show what
she meant; Amanda acquiesced. ``You see how good she is,'' Albrecht
said.

   But not everybody sees that goodness. ``People regularly come up
to me when I am walking my dogs and say the dogs should be
gassed,'' Albrecht said. ``Can you imagine? Gassed. With our
history. Gas them all, they say. It makes me shudder.''

   The obverse of such anger is an overflowing canine compassion.
Take Cora. Her mother was found injured on a Greek beach and
brought to Berlin for treatment. Abandoned dogs are regularly
brought back from vacations in Spain and Italy for salvation
through German goodness.

   ``People here are crazy,'' Wiedenmann said. ``They'll do
anything for a dog and they really, deeply believe that dogs should
be well-adjusted psychologically.''
